A clear medium to dark blonde beer, with a large, frothy/fizzy, lightly lacing, mostly lasting white head.The aroma is lightly to moderately malty (caramel, toasted grain), moderately hoppy (grapefruit. apricot, pine), with notes of toffee and alcohol. The flavor is moderately to heavily sweet, lightly to moderately acidic, moderately bitter. Medium to full body, oily/syrupy texture, lively carebonation, very long finish with heavy bitterness, moderately alcoholic. First of all, this beer is pretty good in every field, without being spectacular in any. Unbalanced but tasty, abrasive but very perfumey. Prototypical Westcoast DIPA, straightforward and with some flaws, but very tasty, I have to admit.

Bottle. Pours orange with a fluffy white head. Floral and citric hoppy aroma with some toffee malts. The flavor has floral, citric, and earthy hops, with toffee sweet malty notes. A little bit on the old side for an IPA, but still pretty good. Hopefully Ill have the chance to re-rate this at a fresher point. As it stands right now, at about 6 months it still drinks pretty good.

Bomber. Not the outstanding brew that I was expecting. Advertised as being Super Hopped, but I found the hoppiness and the bitterness to be quite tame.Has all of the charactoristics of a good Double India Pale Ale and is well balanced. No bitter punch at the end. Possible that I had a bad bottle as I did not find this until mid-October.

Hazy amber with a finger of puffy white head that retreated quickly, leaving small rings of lacing.  Hoppy aroma - grapefruit lemon and orange with hints of caramel malt.  Taste of citrus fruits, pine and apricot giving way to caramel malts, honey and a hint of earthiness.  Very smooth. My bottle had a couple months of age on it but very little of the hop profile has faded.
(Bottle 25/10-2011) Low white head, clear orange color, hoppy aroma, dry bitter hoppy taste. Excellent beer.

golden yellow, hazy, with just over a finger of foamy white head. Fairly good lacing.   Nose is Grapefruit, pine, a little lemon zest, some floral notes as well. Pretty pungent.

Taste has a omewhat faded hop profile, theres the remnants of grapefruit, citrus, and pine. Its definitely a shell what I imagine it was fresh. Theres a little astringency/bitterness on the backend and just a little bit of alcohol (taste and warmth) in the finish. Sizable malt base with a good bit of caramel sweetness. Probably a little too sweet (has that candied fruit taste). Finish is semi-dry.  Medium body, light carbonation. Stick and resinous, but not all that smooth and certainly not crisp.

Refrigerated bottle poured into a chalice.  Pours light hazy orange with small bright white head.  Some lacing, medium body, sticky texture, and nice light hoppy aroma.  Taste is light grapefruit and powerful pine.  Pretty good, but not a fan of so much pine, I have had better DIPAs.

this is an outstanding beer had it in bottle when i visited california in july 2011. was told had just been bottle. amazing hop aroma and flavor the mouth fell is great considering the alcohol content. drink this beer!

07-OCT-2011, bottle @home, from "Ølbutikken".
Cloudy light orange with low white head. A bit pale...
Lovely hoppy nose. Citrus, flovers and pine. 
Taste is even more the same. Backed up by some malty sweetness that. Ould not be guessed from the color. 
Lovely creaminess with ok carbonation. Really one of the better IPAs.
Bottle at Mikkeller bar. Golden-orange colour with an off-white head. Aroma is apricot, hop, malt. Flavour is hop, malt, apricot, fruit, citrus. Nice beer.

Sampled @ SBWF 2011 on September 29. Pour hazy golden with a big white head. Smell is malty with citrus fruits, peaches, slight amounts of ash and some alcohol, Taste is sweet and malty with citrusy hops being dominant. Its also quite spicy with black pepper and other spices adding to the complexity of a very good IIPA.
Sampled at SB & WF 2011. Pours pale yellow with a big white head. Smells and tastes sweet hoppy with a similar finish.

Stockholm Beer & Whisky Festival 2011. Golden beer, offwhite head. Hoppy spicy perfume aroma, milky, malty, fruity notes. Hoppy and milky flavor, creamy, perfume, fruity, some grapefuit. Quite bitter but also with a sweetish profile.

Sample @ SBWF 2011. Pours cloudy amber great off white head leaving lace. Aroma is yeasty citric piny dry soapy sourish. Flavor is caramel citric piny pungent malty fruity bitter. Finishes bitter sweet.
Bottle at SBWF 2011. It poured a hazy golden liquid with a small creamy white head. Sweet and malty DIPA with lots of hops. Very nice.

UPDATED: AUG 25, 2016 Belle couleur cuivrée translucide. Au nez le malt est si puissant quon y perçoit vanille et caramel mais pas tellement loin le profil houblonné est lourd. Vraiment bien balancé entre le malt et lagrume floral.

(65 cl bottle from Toft Vin. BBD: May 1st, 2014.) Pours a slightly hazy, dark golden with medium, off-white head and lace. Aroma is a somewhat dry and mummified hoppy with notes of citrus and alcohol. Oily texture, full-bodied, medium carbonation and a long, bitter finish. Taste is bitter with a touch of what seems like licorice? Girlfriend says: "Its a pity its so bitter. The licorice taste would interest me."
Very very nice. But not as good as the hype, but hey thats more down to personal taste. A seriously top rated SD style double IPA!

Bomber courtesy of thome50.  Pours a clean golden orange with a small head that faded fast to a thin film.  Soft, and pleasant aroma of some grapefruit and orange citrus, some fresh flowers, and a hair of grass.  Simple, yet elegant.  Flavors bright grapefruit skin, Mandarin orange, slightly resinous hops, and a solid malt backbone.  Finish is not even very bitter and is reminiscent of orange juice.  Light bodied and dangerous. Nice. I dig.

Bomber shared by mtjoseph, pours hazy golden orange with slight white head. Aroma is a scotch tape pine with citrus, backed with caramel malt. Taste is very sweet caramel and citrus, with pine on the edges, and finishing clean and dry. Nice well round and easy drinking, alcohol is well hidden.

Dark yellow, lots of white foam. Lovely aroma filled with tropical fruits, notes of vanilla.  Big malt flavour, but the hops still manage to dominate and this without making the taste overly bitter, very well balanced. Some alcohol. Heavy yet surprisingly refreshing.

Pours golden amber with off white head. Aroma is juicy hops, orange, peach, resin, pine, citrus, light bread, light yeast, tropical notes, caramel malts in the background and very light earthy notes. Taste is crispy juicy hops, peach, orange, resin, spice, pine and citrus. Very big and sticky IIPA . <3 !

At a tasting in Shachars house, thanks zvikar, bottle, pours cloudy golden color with a very small white head, hoppy, litchi and citrus fruits aroma, sweetish flavor, bitter aftertaste, medium body, and overall an excellent beer.

Bottle split with mcberko. Pours translucent orange/brown with a small, white, lasting head. Aroma of piney hops, caramel malts and tropical fruits such as mango and kiwi. Flavour of piney hops, honey, caramel, orange peel, some herbal spice, resin and some light floral notes. Sweet and smooth to start, leading to a bitter dry finish. Amazingly good.

Bomber thanks to bigmmartin, pours a hazy orange with a decent white head and some spotty lacing, the aroma has a good amount of citrus and juicy hops, the flavor actually didnt blow me away like I was hoping for it to, seemed like the hops and the bitterness died down some, the flavor seemed to be more sweet than bitter, still enjoyable just not up there for DIPAs for me.

22oz bottle in a snifter.  Pours copper with a thick, lacy, lingering, light beige head.  Aroma strong of citrusy hops, caramel and doughy malts, and some alcohol.  Flavor like they describe it - lots of hops, balanced by the malts, and a dry, bitter finish.  Average texture.  A good beer, but not the best of this style, and I feel like their IPA is better.

Pours a very cloudy pale gold with very little head. Very piney aroma with some sweeter hints of grapefruit and pineapple. Taste is very well balanced. A little sweet and fruity up front, but with a nice dry, hoppy finish. Good doses of both pine and citrus hops. Palate is pretty unremarkable. More or less flat. Bad bottle. Pretty good overall but quite disappointing, especially the lack of carbonation. Pours a very cloudy pale gold with very little head. Very piney aroma with some sweeter hints of grapefruit and pineapple. Taste is very well balanced. A little sweet and fruity up front, but with a nice dry, hoppy finish. Good doses of both pine and citrus hops. Palate is pretty unremarkable. More or less flat. Bad bottle. Pretty good overall but quite disappointing, especially the lack of carbonation.

Bottle. First bottle was delicious - everything I expect in an IIPA but with a very pleasing sweet malt contrast to the bitterness - for whatever reason its yeast qualities reminded me of the best of Rogues beers. Second bottle was compromised somehow - or my taste buds were off - but this is a delicious beer. Wish both bottles had been as tasty as the first.

22oz bottle.
Golden amber brew with lots of off-white head.  Lots of tropical fruit and citrus aromas with some honey sweetness.  Flavor is bitter but not overly so with grapefruit, caramel malt, and a mango finish.

Big bottle courtesy of gunnar. Pale clear golden with a two inch thick, creamy, almost gelatinous head leaving good lacing. Light malty, and light floral and herbal aroma. Sweet, alcoholic and bitter. Full bodied and juicy.

22 oz. bottle, split with Matts_Property, pours a hazy golden orange with a tiny white head. Strong piney and resinous hops on the nose, with just enough caramel malt to back. Flavour is intensely hoppy with absolute truckloads of piney and resinous hops that completely cover the palate - and yet somehow nothing is out of balance. Some fruity characteristics blend in with the hops, as well as some caramel. Not even that much bitterness, but intense fruity and resinous hops linger on and on. Remarkably well-made - a pinnacle IIPA.

UPDATED: AUG 26, 2016 Bottle from Boxbeer. (Bottled 4 months ago)
Pours amber with a firm head. 
a lot of caramel malt, alcohol, oranges, dark fruits and grapes. 
Dont see this as a top 50 iipa.

UPDATED: SEP 8, 2013 Rerate: (dont like to do these unless for change of a couple of points, or - in this case, due to having a fresh bottle to rate) Thanks to Jackie & ck1! Bomber with a 5/4/2013 bottle date. Aroma piney citrus with some faint caramel. Still mildly impressive. Taste is citrus pine, tasty, with a great peppermint finish - similar to the winter Yulesmith; how do they do that? Finishes bittersweet with a nice combination of each, slightly more bitter, but the lovely swwetness of the peppermint.  Thanks so much for giving me another, bro! Original rating: Bomber shared with ck1 that he had shipped from the PHX area (second bomber didnt make it, unfortunately) - thanks bro!  Pours unclear yellow orange with some head.  Aroma is pine, citrus and some woodiness.  Taste is citrus pine, with some thickness, finishing quite bitter and long.  Good flavor.  Looking for this for a long time, and it was very nice - missing the fruit flavors up front that make Dreadnaught and Double Jack exceptional in my opinion.  ck1 says somewhere between Dread and Ruination is summer Yulesmith.  One possible item was that the 2010 date was noticed on the bottle after finishing; age perhaps a factor, although I did not get "old hops" while drinking. 8-4-9-4-15
Nose is heavy hops, red grape, rosehip, pepper, feel Is medium, carb is broad, taste Is menthol, heavy fresh hops, some lemon, later more bitter hops

Bottle (8,5%). Golden  light orange, cloudy, average and mostly lasting head. Moderate, malty and sweetish, very fruity aroma, lots of piney and citrus hoppyness, some caramel. Body is medium to full, malty and sweetish flavor, very fruity, lots of dry piney and citrus hoppyness, faint caramel. Finish is average to long, malty and lightly sweetish, fruity, huge amounts of bit sharp piney and citrus hoppyness, some alcohol. Really nice IPA, but in the finish bitterness gets bit sharp and harsh  not so much fruitiness anymore. Also 8,5% is bit too much considering the body, nice one though.

This may just be the best beer Ive ever tasted. It is initially like many exceptional IPAs out there. Then the aftertaste kicks in and its something I cant quite describe, but it makes you want to take another drink immediately. SO GOOD. Is this the liquid version of crack?

UPDATED: AUG 14, 2011 Bottle @ Sorbon, Bromma July 31 2011. Slightly hazy light orange / dark yellow color, pretty big white head with very large bubbles. Very fruity smell, also bitterness and grapefruit. Taste so much grapefruit, hops and bitterness! Fantastic, love this beer!

Great beer. I really enjoyed the balance between dry finish and the lingereing feel of the alcohol. The hops are very prominent but not overly bitter. The malts are not too sweet and they simply compliment the wonderful hop flavors. I find this beer very easy to drink for the gravity. 2011 release reads 8.5 percent not 9.5

Found this gem in the craft beer aisle at the Whole Foods in Scottsdale north of East Princess Blvd. Slightly hazy bright amber with orange highlights supporting a 3 finger light khaki head. Huge grapefruit and tangerine aroma. Big citrusy, piney hoppy flavor profile with stiff malt rails keeping everything in perfect balance. Supporting flavors of toffee, caramel, milk chocolate and spicy white pepper come to play as well. Soft, full texture and a quick, dry, citrusy and mildly bitter finish. IPAs dont get much better than this.

Tasted on 7/14/11 from a bomber bottle, there is no bottle date, but I assume this is the 2011 batch, as it was just sent to me in a trade this week.  Pours hazy golden-orange with a thick off-white head that slowly recedes to thick and rocky lace, leaving very thick lace residue along the inside of the glass.  The nose is intense resin, citrus, and tropical fruit hops, along with a bunch of sweet caramel and bread malt with just a hint of cinnamon baking spices.  The flavor is very intense bitter resin, citrus, herbal, and tropical fruit hops along with the sweet flavor of caramel and malty bread, finishing with light cardamom and cinnamon.  The body is full and very oily with average carbonation and a long sweet caramel and bread malt with intensely bitter hops.
Bottle. Pours clear golden with a huge creamy white head. Aroma of bready malts, with some nice fruity hops lurking in the background.Taste is dry and fruity hops, some spices towards the end.

Shared bottle at local tasting, thanks to gunnar. ABV is 8.5%. Golden colour, huge white head. Sweetish aroma of malts and orange marmalade. Distinctly hoppy flavour throughout, very bitter finish. Maybe not very complex, but good.

shared bomber on 7/4/11 purchased at Wallys in LA.  deep golden pour with a 1/4" white head.  deep citrus hop nose with a touch of spice.  medium body - very smooth - loaded with citrus bitterness - nice malt balance.  sweet light fruits linger.  zesty.  dry lasting bitter finish.

Pours golden yellow with a huge rocky beige head. Smells of fresh grapefruit, orange, honey, grass, mango, lemon and some floral hops. Taste of grapefruit, lemon, pine, honey, caramel malts, mango and some orange. Mouthfeel medium thick and finish is long and citrus bitter.

[Bottle] Pours a clear golden amber at first until you disturb the yeast,then a lightly clouded orange hue, head formation is good although not particularly enduring. Strong hop aroma, plenty of piney citrus and pineapple, theres some yeasty spice too. Lots of spice and bitterness on the palate, tingling and teasing the tongue. Theres a light breadiness from the malt while the hops also show a little pineapple juice towards the end. Its the dry bitterness that dominates though lingering long, even a little salty in the aftertaste.

This is a DIPA! Fresh, full of Christmas in July! Pours a very, very pale amber with a very nice head that sticks around even as the glass warms.  Tons of citrus and sweet pine aroma.  Taste is exactly how all DIPAs should be, pineapple, sweet but not over powering, hop bite, malt a mere second cousin.  The beer is well balanced without compromising style.  Im sick of DIPAs coming in as being "malt balanced." Malt needs to take a back seat to hops in a DIPA and this does just that. Excellent beer and one I will enjoy fresh.
user_location: Morro Bay via Orange County, California, USA

text:
2011 bottle. Drank Fourth of July, 2011. 

APPEARANCE: Elegant in its straightforwardness. Pure gold. Completely translucent. Head is pure white, 1 finger, medium retention, limited lacing. Zero nuanced hues to the color of the ale or head. 


AROMA: Pine, citrus, floral, caramel, honey, tropical fruit. Nose is beautifully balanced between hops and malt. 

TASTE: Hop-forward, as expected. Bitter grapefruit peel is prominent. Plethora of resinous piney hops. Malt backbone subdued by the extreme hoppiness. 

MOUTH FEEL: Highly quaffable. Pleasant hop bite. Nice tangy bitterness. Semi-dry finish. 

OVERALL: A fine example of the style. Quite hoppy on palate.

Note that this bottle was from last year. Pours a hazy slightly pale yellow. The aroma is a bit weak at first but grows with a couple of minutes in the glass, but it is the taste that stand out here. Loads of pineapple, both perfectly ripe and freh as well as tinned. Medium bitter with a dry finish.

Hazy orange pour with nice white head. Aroma is an onslaught of citrus, orange peel, honey and vanilla. Taste is nice and floral with lots of hops up front and a nice maltiness balance. Great dipa and fresh also.

Very nice DIPA.  Rated from memory that i will update when i crack my fresh bottle fro this year.  Aroma is very citrus heavy with grassy sweetness.  Taste is grassy and citrus with good malt presence.

Bottle from Ledgers. Summers here - time to crack one into my Alesmith glass. Pours a cloudy amber with a foamy head and nice lacing. The aroma starts off a malty caramel, but ends dominated by piney / citrus hops. Smooth flavors. Sticky finish. The malts add to the complexity and balances out a bit of the hop bite. Velly nice stuff..

650 ml bottle.
Pours an orange colour with a large foamy white head. Very fruity aroma with mandarin orange, grapefruit and strong hops. Flavour of sweet fruits, caramel, light bready malts and very strong floral hops. Full bodied with a thick mouthfeel and a strong, hoppy, fruity finish. Clearly one of the best DIPAs Ive tasted - massive amount of hops, not too sweet and very smooth.

Sehr süßer und intensiver Hopfenantrunk. Die Süße verschwindet schnell und macht dunklen Bitternoten Platz. Trotz der starken Hopfennoten wirkt das Bier süffig; die Würzigkeit nimmt zu. Wenig alkoholisch, breit hopfig, dabei bleibt eine gewisse Trockenheit nicht aus. Vergleichsweise wenig bitterer Abgang mit intensiver und runder Hopfigkeit  blumig, etwas nach Apfel und Melone. Kann begeistern! 12/12/12/13/9/13

Big bottle shared at BrewDog bar. Bright, hazy amber/orange with a gushing white head that never really disappears. Caramel, orange, subtle citrus on the nose. Big sweet hop taste with a classic American IPA resinous, citric finish. Slight alcohol burn without being unpleasant.

Bomber from 2010. Pours with a hazy amber, huge white bubbly head that fills up the goblet, and take a while to settle to something that is even drinkable through. Nice hoppy aroma, huge bitter taste, soapy and delicious, creamy and nicely carbonated throughout. The bitterness actually keeps on growing for good minute or more - need more of this and would like to try it fresh!
Golden Hazy Pour with big white head. Nose is citrusy. Lovely medium bodied and smooth mouthfeel with a crisp bitter finish definitely an outstanding IPA.

Breweries really should avoid naming two different beers the same thing and hope that seasons will remove any confusion, because it doesnt. This is the firework one (the photo should be changed on this website to clear up any additional confusion). Received as an extra in a trade with stawn. Thanks. Beer poured into a snifter.

Beer is orangish to yellow and has a slight haze to tit. Forms a two fingered white head of small to medium bubbles. Head completely coats the sides of the glass with lacing. Carbonation is moderate and steady. Feeds the head well.

Im sitting about a foot from the beer and I can smell it from here. Big hop aroma, a slight yeast funk, the yeast did not completely settle out of the beer and when I popped it they floated back up into the beer. Oh well. There is some malt sweetness in this beer as well. Very strong, citrus hop aroma.

Beer is medium bodied and has a good hop flavor in the mid-palate, definitely citrus hops. The bitterness is not bad. This beer is less malty than many DIPAs Ive been trying lately and this is good. Drinkability is really high. Beer is not overly sweet. I fear that the hops may have diminished in this beer, I should try and get one of these more fresh than this but there still is significant bitterness. The reason why I think it may have faded is there is a slight sulfur aftertaste to this beer that I attribute to fallen hops. Overall its a great beer and this sulfur flavor is mild and not distracting. There is basically no aftertaste but the bitterness does grow the more you drink. I think the body and feel of this IPA a lot.

Serving type: bottle

he beer pours medium brown with a very light tan head that has no head, retention or lacing. 

The aroma is very hoppy with a muted maltiness. 

The taste is very interesting, but not sure if thats a good thing. There is lots of hoppiness here but there is something else to, that just brings a weirdness to the beer.

[22oz bottle at BrewDog Bar, Edinburgh] Hazy golden pour with a thin white head. Big citrus and pine DIPA aromas, alongside some sweet caramel malt. Flavours are  as youd expect  hop-forward (tropical and more citrus) before a warming sweet alcohol finish. Deep flavours, and a great mouthfeel. Very nice indeed [15032011]

Aquired in a trade from thome50. He threw it in as an extra. Thanks. Wanted to give this a couple more points but the amount of alcohol left present and stinging quality of carbonation left my taste buds wanting...more of this and a wanting to be left alone so I could taste the awesome nuances. This finished hot, dry and stingy. Stingy in the sense of a ton of sharp carbonation that attacks your tongue occuping its time.this bad boy left a huge head...again and again. It really never faded. Deep gold and not clear. Sweet pineapple on the nose. When I drank it I was trying to figure out what I was tasting. It was the malts....sweet, almost tropical. That dry hoppy ifinish rushes in to take all the glory from the malts. Its nicely balanced. I like it. This is my first AleSmith brew...and not my last. Love it.

Aroma is full of citrus hops, pine, grapefruit, orange.  Pours a slightly hazy goldenrod with a massive rocky head, great retention.  Flavor: lots of sticky, resiny hops, pine, tropical fruits, grapefruit tang.  Flavoring hops really take the reins, with a nice caramel/crystal malt backbone.  Bittering hops show up in the finish and linger for a while.  Really great IPA.
UPDATED: JUL 29, 2012 Very hoppy citrusy nose, body is perfectly balanced without excessive bitterness, light on complexity is whats preventing this from taking off into the high 4s

Bottle from beermerchants.com. Drunk with slothez watching the superbowl.
Hazy golden pour with a lingering off white head. Aroma was enticingly sniffable: plenty of resinous hop and citrus character with some background sweet malts. Good stuff. Nice body and fullish mouthfeel. Similarly sculpted flavour to the nose with an abundance of fruity hops tangling with a dollop of sweet malts. Bitterness spot on. Really satisfying IPA that punches its weight. Top class.
.

Bottle shared with Jonas and Johannes at Rotary, 2010-02-18 Göteborg
AR: pine, pineapple, wild strawberries, apricots
AP: dark amber/honey colored body, wee fizziness - high stead yellowish white head. Johannes documented the foam from underneth: - it looks like the milk way, stars glittering!
F: grape fruit, pine, apricot, high bitterness, salty, very fruity finish, alcholic
Yolk: isnt that fruity, more relexed but still refreshingly good!

(Bottle, 0.65 l, at Pikkulintu)  The beer poured golden and clear. Its head was quite large and white. Aroma was very hoppy, it had also citricness, floweriness and sweetness. Palate was medium bodied with medium carbonation. Flavours were hops, citicness, fruitiness, floweriness, sweetness, malts and bitterness. Aftertaste was hoppy, fruity and bitter. A really tasty and good double IPA.

Unclear orange with an off-white head. Aroma is caramel, malty and heavy hoppy, citrus, pine needles and grapefruit. Flavor is rather sweet and very bitter. Dry and lasting bitter finish. Excellent stuff. 171110

Got this guy on sale at Whole Foods.  Nose is very spicy, floral, and full of alcohol/malts. Color is a bright orange and extremely hazy.  This beer is complete with all of its trub, yeast layer and hops.  Very bitter and fresh, considering the amount of grain and alcohol presence.  Consistent as it warms, this beer is truly delightful and a great brew to indulge in year round.  Kudos to the homebrewers in Sand Diego!

Poured into a snifter. Big thanks to piclee and psiweaver for this.

4.5 A: Hazy yellow orange color. Three fingers of creamy/frothy hybrid with excellent retention and plenty of lacing.

4.5 S: Piney, floral, and citrusy. At first it has an uncomfortable resemblance to Pine-Sol, but then an underlying layer of bitterness brings it back to the realm of beer. Pine and orange are the strongest aromas, with lemon zest and pineapple following. Really nice. I wish I could give it a 4.75.

4.5 T: Orange and pineapple are beating my tongue senseless. Tropical fruits, pine, grapefruit, and herbalness underneath. Lots of flavor hops, in fact maybe the most flavor hops Ive encountered, but theres an annoying bready/doughiness getting in the way. I usually like a barleywine-esque DIPA, but in this case the hops are the star and the malts are just distracting. Still, this is a very tasty brew.

4.0 M: Thicker medium body. Again, the malts are pissing me off. This falls into the middle ground between dry, bitter DIPAs and barleywine DIPAs. If this picked a side, Id be happier. Still, good creaminess and smooth.

4.5 D: This is a great brew. If the malts were a bit cleaner, this would be a 5 for sure. AleSmith knows there shit, I learned that a while ago.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 08-21-2010 01:20:05
65cl, Vintage 2010, at 8.5%Vol, as YuleSmith Holiday Ale, American brew, thx to Jeppe!, complex bitter brew, balanced, hazy, rocky head, very good Summer brew, yet expensive!

Bottle courtesy of nbutler11, thank you sir!  Bright golden color, hi carb, huge ice cream cone head with great retention.  Great aroma of pine and lime.  Flavor has tons of citrus, light pine, but great sweet malt balance.  Scant and subtle bitterness.  Wonderful.

Old rate. 650ml bottle courtesy of Sprague. Pours a rich copper-red body beneath a small frothy white head. Floral hops, effervescence that greatly translates through to flavour and finish. Great blend of malts and potent hops. Somewhat piny and resinous. Stinging bitterness, but not overly so. Really wonderful and deep.
7 oz from a new years tasting transported back from Portland......very tasty; nice lacing from small head; hoppy, citrus nose; smooth taste with that hoppy bite; very very good beer.

Bottle from Ølbutikken, Copenhagen. Saved this until Christmas, and what a treat this is! Pours a splendid, hazy deep honey orange with a massive white creamy head. Nose is floral hops, grass, kiwi and hints of grapes and earthy tones, all with a solid malt backing. Taste is honey, pale malts, grassy hops and smooth, fruity bitterness with hints of orange and citrus. This is a beer both robust and elegant at the same time; both with a magnificent richness in flavor and aroma while being highly drinkable. Fresh and yet heavy, this is a rock solid, well-balanced top of the line DIPA from AleSmith, well deserving its monumental rating. A nice way to round off my Christmas beers, along with the Decadence 2010 (see own rating). Cheers, and a Happy New Year to all the RB people out there! :-D

Cant beleive I found a bottle of this in Winter! Firstly it wasnt in primne condition, but it was still very good. Judging by the Winter Yulesmith I can see just how good it can be. Thick and viscous. Lots of pine and citrus everywhere, if slightly dulled by the age. Gets an extra .5/5 because of this. Really, really have to try this fresh!

Had previously bought the red version and didnt think it was very good, but figured Id take a shot on this one anyone.  Boy am I glad I did.  Pours a bright dark gold hazy color with nice amount of frothy white head.  Aroma is lots of tropical citric fruits and slight sweetness.  Flavor starts sweet and fruity, like sugared grapefruits and mangos, which then shifts into a bitter hoppy finish, but not overpowering, rather perfectly balanced.  Alcohol you can tell is there, but no burn or overpowering tastes.  Overall, this is truely an amazing beer, exceptionally balanced, and perfect to be drank any time of the year or for any occasion.

14th December 2010. At the Euston Tap with Harrisoni. Cheers to Ian for lashing out on this breathtakingly expensive but wonderful beer. Hazy gold beer, fluffy white head. Soft dry palate with light carbonation. Creamy malt base with gorgeous hops. Mild pink grapefruit, orange, mango and guava. Lovely creamy finish. Hugely drinkable, I could honestly drink this till I passed out. Lovely!
hoppy aroma,sweet aroma,amber, clear, white foam, light sweetness, medium bitterness, medium body, creamy, soft carbonation, bitter.

Golden colour and hazy, white head, lasting. Aroma is heavy hoppy, citrus, yeasty, faint iron, sweetness too, malty, toast. Flavor starts nice sweet, then the bitterness takes over, heavy bitter. Texture is creamy and dry, lively carbonation.
bottle from stefanj.  poured yellowish gold with a white head.  aroma was fruity, citrus, and melon.  flavor was fruity, orange, pine, and cream.  body was medium with fizzy carbonation.

Bottle from Beermerchants.com. Hazy amber pour with a beige head. Aromas of citrus, quite floral, pear, mango and peach. Has that no-nonsense-no-fuckin-about classic American IPA nose. Very nice flavours of pear, lemon zest, lime, orange rind. Good fruity tang, crisp zesty flavours. Fruity, sharp hop finish. Very nice indeed.

Bottle Euston Tap. Drank with Ken. Cheers. My White whale. Pink grapefruit and loads of citrus hops melon so rich tropical fruit. Lovely smelling beer. Full but soft in the mouth in the same time. Its brilliant b the way the finish of pale malt hop tropical fruit and regined bitterness is stunning. Mouthfeel is stunning. Very fruit led

This is an odd one for me. Firstly I was blown away to get my hands on this, though I seem to have slightly bad luck with Alesmith beers. Firstly with a bottle of Yulesmith Winter which I thought was going to be the summer and turned out to be a bottle that was about 2 years old,the beer was still pretty good, but hop-wise I think it had passed its best. Here I open the Summer Yule and am greeted by ridiculous carbonation, an out of control head that you would expect to see from an over conditioned Belgian, or an Alvinne beer with a very yeasty almost metallic aroma. I decid not to cry and leave the beer to one side for 15 mins and sure enough the carbonation had calmed down alot leaving a glowing golden pint with a massive white head. Aroma had pulled itself together somewhat to with loads more tropical notes than expected, very fruity, pineapple, mango, blood orange, citrus peel, spice, but still a bit more yeast and a slight metallic tinge right at the end. Behind that there are caramel and honey notes with butter and creamy malt. Flavour starts with a nice vanilla like entry, then into runny honey, spice and then a nice emerging citrus bitterness from the hops with more blood orange, pink grapefruit and sweet resin. Really has a lot of honey running through it. Finish comes about with more floral notes, a touch of perfume ad a wonderful dryness that is quite palate coating after a while. Very well balanced brew with perhaps the best alcohol control Ive encountered in this style. This really could be a hearty IPA rather than a DIPA, the balance seems to have been handled very, very well. I dont know whether my bottle was a bit of an unlucky odd one as far as the conditioning was concerned, I suspect that it has been a bit of an odd one out, but I can still see many great things in this beer, and refuse to downgrade it due to bad luck. Still not as good as Green Flashs IIPA, but like I say under the circumstances its hard to say for sure. Very drinkable, and without a doubt it is the most refreshing DIPA Ive ever had.

YuleSmith is a quenching, hoppy "double" IPA. Appearance: Clear copper color and a creamy beige head with good retention. Flavor: Starts out with a bite of hops, but a perfect balance of maltiness and a dry finish leave you thirsting for that next sip. Aroma: The aroma starts with a heady citrusy and floral feel, and a slight overtone of vanilla. Mouthfeel (body/texture): Smooth, medium-bodied. Warm mouthfeel from the high alcohol content. Feels lush and full in the mouth.

....I know, I just copied the bottle description, lazy but true, this is a phenominal DIPA.

Bottled 65cl. Hazy orange copper with a medium-sized chunky spotty lacing off-white head. Grapefruit, citrusy piney hops and mandarine orange are most present in the nose. Good bitterness. Fruity with a wonderful hop profile. Perfect balance. Almost full bodied. Mandarine orange and grapefruit are most present in the finish which is dry. A top notch delicious double IPA and a very good example of the style.

Bottle at The Cads Pure Mad Rocket Mon The Beezer Tasting. Pours a not completely clear gold with a huge, white head. Big, tropical fruit aroma with some light pine. Nice and sweet, with some caramel and honey, more tropical fruits like pineapple and passionfruit, along with grapefruit bitterness. Medium bodied with average carbonation. Has a sweet finish with refreshing, fruity hops, light warmth and stickiness. Also some bready yeast notes. Excellent beer.

Bottle, Cads drink up weve got a table and we need to drink Mikkeller, mon the beezers and leave at 6 epic tastings

Lovely hoppy notes, citurs, nougat and pine on aroma.

Taste is honey, nougat, citrus, peaches, big fruity complex going on , excellent drinkability, mouth feel is sublime, something I can drink long into the summer nights, big hpoppy and bold, surprisingly strong malt character which I appreciate.

Great to drink, even out of season.
Bottle. Hazy golden with medium white head. Flavour is malt, caramel, fruit and plenty of aroma and bitter hops.

Summer 2009 Version

Pours a golden color that is slightly hazy and has a good white head. The aroma consists of some floral hops that ride behind a bunch of fruity citrus hops. The taste is quite hoppy, but not nearly as much as I would have expected from the nose--everything is well integrated, it just needs to be taken up a notch or two. The body is medium with good carbonation. Good drinkability overall, but not quite as good as some of AleSmiths other offerings.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 09-24-2009

A Mes rate. Bottle at The Cads Pure Mad Rocket Mon The Beezer Tasting.Hazy yellow gold with a thin white head. Massive tangerine and a hint of soap on the nose. A really really good hit of pink grapefruit in the background with a good hit of sugar. Similar flavour. Good bitterness. Good mouthfeel. Very nice. Yule summer??? Really???

22 oz bottle. Hazy golden orange with a gigantic off white head that leaves some lacing. Aroma is lemon, sugary light caramel, pine and light funk. The flavor is bitter throughout with a dry malt backbone. Medium body with very active carbonation and a frothy mouth feel. Not the freshest bottle but still a damn good beer, the uber carbonation makes me wonder if there is something going on in the bottle. Would love to try this fresh.

Pours a very cloudy deep golden color with a thick white head.  Aroma is full of crisp centennial hop, grapefruit, some mar-zen, lactic, and oh yeah a little citrus.  Flavor is quiet complex.  I can pick up hops, orange peels, slight booze, and corriander. Leaves a very down hop hop finish.  Very earthy this one is.
Big fan of this hoppy, yeasty little number. Hell of a punch and plenty of delicious flavour. Incredibly moreish.

I suspect this guy might have sat on the shelf too long.  The aroma is pine, citrus, honey, solvent.  The appearance is a hazy yellow/gold, white head.  The flavor is more caramel, honey, pine, solvent again.  The finish is a harsh pine and resin bitterness.  Medium-bodied.  decent, not up to the hype.  But again, this was on a half price rack, and probably went past its due date.

Bottle. Moderate malt note of roasted, moderate to heavy hops of pine and orange, light soap for the yeast, with hints of pineapple, pepper and alcohol. Head is large, frothy turning rocky, white with good slippery lacing and is fully lasting. Color is hazy amber. Flavor starts lightly sweet and moderately acidic, then finishes lightly acidic and moderately bitter. Palate is medium, oily with a lively carbonation and a lightly alcoholic finish. Excellent, I wouldnt have expected anything less from a DIPA brewed by Alesmith.

Bottle.  Bright orange colour, small white head. Aroma has lots of pine, citrus, lime, caramel, quite rough, some spices. Taste is also rough, yet very pleasurable, heavy on hops and bitterness along with citric and piney notes. Very interesting and complex.

Traded 22oz bottle side-by-side with 3F Arctic Panzer. Cloudy yellow-gold color with a huge foamy head and sheets of lacing. Relatively faint aroma balanced between sweet malt, spicy hops and some pineapple. More full mouthfeel. Lots of malt in the flavor but also a gentle bitterness. Warm, alcohol finish.

Bottle courtest of Hamilton23, thanks Steve.  Again, this is a highly anticpated beer for ole Duder.  Not what I was expecting exactly, but a good beer none the less.  Here we have a lot of ins and outs and a lot of what-have-yous.  I get a few drinks and me and I start bustin out Lebowski.  Anyway, there is a flavor in this beer that Im not quite loving, but I can quite put my finger on it.  Having said that, I shouldnt complain that I have this in my glass right now.  Well done.

Bottle @ Ølkonsortiet xmasbeer tasting. Pours clear golden with a long lasting thin white head.Aroma of citruss, pine, grapefruit, some sweet caramel malt to. Aroma is like nose, nicely balanced bitterness vs maltbase, floral notes, grapefruit. Medium body, long bitter finish. Good stuff 101106

Amber pour with a bug frothy head. Aroma is very citrusy, hops, grassy, slight exotic fruits, some caramel malts to balance. Taste is very fruity hops, stinging bitterness, large malt body, bready malts. With their regular IPA in mind, this was a disappointment. Nevertheless, a decent IIPA.

Bomber served in a tulip and a shaker. This bottle says 8.5% ABV. Pours bright orange, nominal haze, active tiny bubbles, and a medium-large off-white head that lingers effortlessly like a foamy topcoat. Moderate watery lacing. Citrus, grass, and floral hop aroma. Lemon, grapefruit, garden, with light malt behind and a hint of melon. Very lemony. Medium bitter, mildly sweet flavor. This quickly grows more bitter, then dries to near astringency. The maltiness increases and lacing improves as the liquid warms. Medium body, creamy texture, average carbonation. Theres a lot going on here. Im particularly impressed with the effervesence that supports the lengthy head retention. I poured the second half of the bottle into a shaker and the head and a foamy lacing was still holding 30 minutes later!

At a tasting, thanks Eyal, pours yellow with a medium head, powerful aroma of pineapple, apricot jam and full floral spectrum, dry with flavors of peach, honey, orange, litchi and grapefruit, pretty zesty, full bodied, great beer.

Foggy, light amber with a head resembling stiff egg whites.  Lacing hugs the sides nicely.  I wish they would extend the appearance rating from 5 to 10 so I could give it a 9.  Floral nose and citrus on the tongue with alcohol coming through dry at the end.  Plain malts with a slight honey flavor.

Grapefruit juice from the moment I opened it. From there a wonderful look and taste and a better finish. It pours out a hazy golden with a white fluffy head. The aroma as I said was grapefruit, pine, citrus and a very nice malt backbone. The flavor was similar except in reverse. The malt came through up front followed by a huge hop hit in the back end. the finish was bitter sweet because I only had one.

Excellent citrus in the smell.  The pour maintained a golden appearance with frothy top.  This beer has a big time hoppy taste and that is what I paid up for.  Overall I really like this one and kind of feel like my rating is possibly a little low actually.  Very solid all around.

At a tasting, thanks zvikar, smallish creamy head, hazy light orange colour, aroma of orange marmalade, pine, apricot, peach, citrus and a touch of malt in the back, flavour of peach, dried pressed apricot, rose petals and lasting herbal presence, very strong bitterness whichis not overpowering but fills quite refreshing. Extremely enjoyable.

bottle pours a very lively light gold with a big off white head.  Aroma is all over the place, but very nice.  Notes of grape, peach, grapefruit, rock candy, floral in a honeysuckle way, even light notes of white wine.  Flavor has strong citrus upfront, very juicy with bitter rind elements and a bit of sweet grassy malts.  Ends with a nice dry pine and grapefruit bite and just a hint of alcohol.  This is good stuff.

Bottle at a tasting: very hoppy both in the aroma in flavor, grapefruit, a bit of lychee, a bit peaches, a bit of pine and lots of mango all from the hops, caramel malt, bisquity malt, great flavorfull DIPA.

Winter (07)
A: snifter. pours an opaque vibrant amber, major red hues. medium khaki colored head. decent retention rate. nice curtain lacing.

S: huge malt aroma, caramel, apples, some maple syrup. ligh citrus hop aroma.

T: big caramel malt flavors. some apples, like apple juice. nice light citrus hop flavors, some green raisins.

M: full bodied. higher carbonation than I would like. huge chewy palate.

Summer 07(consumed July 08)

A: snifter. pours a cloudy, deep orange color, with a slightly off-white head. Mild retention. great lacing.

S: I can smell the hops being two feet away from the glass. Nice rich and hearty hop aromas, almost burning the nostrils. Tons of citrus and pine in there. Wonderful, sweet malts as well.

T: some strange hints of tobacco. big malts supply the major backbone to the beer, very tasty. The hops come in with some citrus characteristics, but I get more earthy flavors than anything. Huge pine flavors, along with some raw earth tones.

M: Thick and hearty. low to mild carbonation level. very rich.

D: Very nice DIPA. my burps are delightful. I am glad I let it mellow out for a year, but you really couldnt tell that much difference.

Tried at Blind Tasting with THeDiabolical DrBayern, Uncle Steve, Uncle Tom, Barrister Bob and Brian the Beer Pimp.  Poured a dark copper color, somewhat hazy.  Nice hop aroma.  Liked the thick lacy white ehad.  Liked the blend of maltiness and hops.  Hop aftertaste was well balanced.
what can you say?! one of the best beers around. thanks to the guys at Belmont Station for stocking it!!

Beautiful, unique pour.  Huge white shaving cream head, fading to soap bubbles, vanishing but leaving good lacing.  Nose of sweet fruit (peaches), caramel and sweet malts, orange, and hops, hops, hops.  Taste a bit too bitter even for this old hop head, and even a bit too metallic.  Long "suck a nail" metallic bitter finish.  Average palate.  Will give it another try.  Surely good, but not a Sculpin, a 90-minute, a Ruination, or a Hop Wallop.
22 oz Bottle -- Pours hazy orange with a small off-white head.  Aromas of apples, caramel, and yeast.  Floral, citrus, and resin hops.  Very syrupy mouth feel.  Feels a little unrefined.

2008, Hazy-gold ^eff full-body high-co2.

Aroma: fresh-resiny-pine-hops.

Taste:
Sweet-pale-malt-syrup bright-fruit T1.
Sweet-malt juicy-leafy-floral-hops T2.
Dryish herbal-hop-resin T3.
Unbalanced, hop-resin dominated.

UPDATED: SEP 25, 2010 Smells grassy and mineral-like with some bright floral hops and maybe a little sour orange.  Flavor is herbal and floral with raw greens hanging out behind a bitter front.  Mouthfeel is medium bodied and leaves a tacky laquered finish to your mouth,  This is really an example of letting the hops stand on their own rather than bolstering them with a hefty grain bill, this is for the hop inclined no doubt.  A nice beer that Im glad to have tried.  Thanks Alesmith.  2010 22oz.

enticing aroma of sticky hops--spicy and floral--with dark fruit and caramel in the background.
hazy orange-gold with rocky yellowish head.
well balanced flavor, nicely sweet with modest bitterness--mild for a dipa.
medium bodied and sticky, lingering bittersweet fruit finish.

finally getting around to trying this one. pour is a golden in color with a one finger off white head. aroma has light citrus, some grapefruit, resins, flowers, and a poke of alcohol on the end. I know this is not as fresh and juicy as it once was but still nice. mouth feel is average and has plenty of carbonation. bitterness picks up in the flavor, resins, pines, citrus, flowers, and a nice countering sweetness to the dry finish. this is smooth and delicious.

Pours hazy golden color with pale white head.  Citrusy aroma smells almost like lemon and orange peel.  Light notes of ginger, cardamom, and peach. Natural oils really come through.  Bitter citrus combines with light residual sweetness for a really well balanced brew.  Malts are barely noticeable but lend the perfect subtle backbone for a crisp ipa.
Bottle: finally got to try this, pours golden amber with a big white head, citrus and hoppy aroma and taste.  Nice mildly bitter finish.  Very good DIPA.

Over-carbonated.  Aroma is good, but muted, the malt is detectable.   Great hop flavor, some bubblegum flavors.  The malt is balanced with the bitterness and enjoyable.  Somewhat balanced but then a layer of hop flavor dominates over everything.  Quite good.  No alcohol taste at all.  Yummy hops and a malt that can handle it, cant ask for much more.

Pours a clear copper orange with a foamy off-white head. Aroma is floral hops, citrus, some pine and a faint bit of sweet malt. Flavors are grassy floral hops with some alcohol. Smooth and creamy with soft carbonation. Well balanced throughout. A great DIPA. Very refreshing and drinkable.

The aroma is delicious - sweet and citrusy. The appearance is thick golden with a huge white head. The flavor starts off a bit sweet but drops to a huge amount of orange zest and bitterness from the hops.

UPDATED: JUL 3, 2011 22oz bottle.  Pours a murky orange with a huge creamy head that leaves mini clouds of foam on the inside of the glass.  Its like the top of a root beer float.  A cool aroma of tropical fruits.  Smooth and warm in the mouth.  Definitely not the punch of hops you would expect from a west coast Double IPA, but just enough to be satisfying, especially for a summer brew.  This beer is absolutely delicious.

Thanks to kaiser81 for sending me this bottle.

The beer pours a hazy golden color with a white head. The aroma is piney and resiny hops and not too much else. Definitely a DIPA. The flavor is an incredible and varied mix of hops. In addition to a little bit of bready malt, I get hop flavors of pine, resin, pineapple, papaya and oranges. Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation. A great beer that lived up to the hype.
Darkish gold, huge grapefruit aroma backed with other tropical/citrus fruit. Flavor is slightly toasty with more hops. Dry smooth finish, nice thick mouth feel.

This is the fifth bottle ive tried and the best to date.  Pours a very foamy thick head.  If you pour it carefully you can avoid a 4 finger head that doesnt want to go away.  Orangy piney flavor that is followed by a lingering tangerine peel finish.  Overall an awesome beer.

Bottle thanks to RegSpeir! Golden with a yeast haze. A light pour provides  a huge creamy head that lasts with the best of them. Bright hoppy nose with complex citrus and fruity hops, very bright citrus and lemon notes no malt aroma to speak of. Sweet, fruity hops take over all senses but hardly leaving any room for malt but is still sweet and not all that bitter for an IIPA. carbonated and smooth feel. warming sensation after a few drinks. Awesome beer.

Bottle from wavers1, thanks a lot! Pours a clear, golden orange with loads of bubbles rising to the massive fluffy white head. The aroma isnt too subdued by the thick layer of suds. It is very floral, citrusy, a little bit of alcohol in there, which comes off as a bit raw. Some sweet, juicy fruitiness in there, tropical fruits. I have a bit of a hard time pinning down the sweetness in here. Fruity, but perhaps a bit candy-like too, or wine gum. The sip is pretty much like you would expect at this point. Short fruity sweetness before massive citric and floral hops cleanse the palate. Bittersweet semidry finish with a moderate alcohol sting and warmth. Body is medium to light, carbonation is pretty mellow and smooth. Overall, its a good drink. I would prefer the alcohol to be hidden a bit more, and maybe its not completely fresh anymore, but i found their regular IPA to be better by a big margin.

Poured from 22oz bomber into half pint.

A - Pours rusty golden in color with a large frothy head. Lots of sticky lacing along the sides of the glass. Somewhat clear, somewhat murky. 

S - Huge amount of bitter citrus and hops in this one. Some sweet citrus as well, mango, orange peels, etc.

T - Hop bomb and lots of bitterness....all in a good way! A nice sweet aftertaste which I think comes from the sweet citrus on the nose. 

M - Light to medium bodied. Very oily but very clean on the finish. Good carbonation.

D - Easy to drink and another awesome CA DIPA!

This is a lovely rich golden color with a full thick chunky white head.  The aroma is rich with grapefruits and tangerines.  An earthy pine is also very prevalent in the nose balanced with deep caramel malts.  Soft sweet fruity flavors of tangerines and grapefruits wash over the palate.  There seems to be a bit of passion fruit as well.  The finish begins sweet and ends very bitter.  The balance in this beer is marvelous.  Overall, an absolutely outstanding beer.

(22oz bottle). 8.5% abv on the bottle.  Pours gold with gusher off-white head.  Aroma of heavy grapefruit, lemon, green mango.  Taste is bitter with some sweet citrusy following (grapefruit).  Medium bodied with fairly thin texture.  Finish is bitter.  Alcohol is making its presence known and I can feel it in my throat and chest.  This is a nice, lighter DIPA.  It has the mouthfeel of a sessionable beer, but the ABV would make that a short session.  Deceptive in that regard.

22 ounce bottle, Summer 2010 YuleSmith.  Served in a tulip glass, the beer pours a hazy golden/orange color with a couple inch frothy off-white head.  Head retention and lacing are both excellent.  Aroma is mostly citrusy hops (tropical fruit, grapefruit, oranges), with some pine hops and sweet malt noticable too.  It tastes like citrusy (grapefruit, tropical fruit, orange peel) and floral hops, peppery spice, and some peaches and bready malt.  Theres also a nice lingering bitter hoppy finish.  Mouthfeel/body is medium, its creamy, a bit slick, and has high carbonation.  I thought it was easy enough to drink.  This is definitely a brew for the hopheads out there!  Id certainly buy this again.

Served from bottle into a Delirium Tremens snifter. Pours a hazy yellow orange with a three finger fluffy white head that remains for quite awhile and subside to a one finger upon sitting for quite some time. Maintained excellent lacing throughout. The aroma was comprised of pineapple, pine, citrus, and mild hops. The flavor was of tropical fruit, malt, with a nice citrus/fruity hop followthrough. It was light on the palate with high carbonation. Overall this was quite a nice IIPA. The aroma of this one was quite nice and refreshing and told you what you were about to get yourself into. The pine flavor in this brew was kind of powerful to me so drinker beware... However I did not find it overwhelming and rather a welcomed change in my past lineups. This is a great IIPA and a must try for the true hopheads out there.

My first beer from the AleSmith brewery.  Pours a lighter amber orange color with a thick white foam head.  Has an aroma of grapefruit and pine with a hint of spice.  Starts sweet and foamy.  Then the hop hit.  Some spice and grapefruit taste through the finish.  Nice carbonation level that kicks up the foaminess of the brew, making it texturally more similar to a belgian strong.  More biting than creamy or resiny.  Unique and tasty.

Big thanks to ericandersnavy for this one.  Great amber pour with a nice fluffy white head.  Huge fresh citrus hops, sticky grapefruit, great florals, and faint vanilla.  Great thickness, sticky chewy hops, nice creamy hop flavor and a smooth finish.
Pineapple and paprika smell. Creamy and bitter. Still dont like IPAs. But I guess as far as this style goes, its good.

(22oz bomber thanks to ericandersnavy) opaque golden, big lasting offwhite head and excellent lacing. Nose of big juicy orange, grapefruit, honey, creamy vanilla and other very fresh citrus aromas! Taste of spicy rye, grapefruit, honey, and bitterness. Finish has alcohol, rye, orange, and quite bitter. Creamy medium thick.

Bottle from a trade with phaleslu. Pours hazy golden orange color with off white head. Citrusy aroma with some pine and caramel. Juicy grapefruit hop flavor with with a touch of caramel sweetness. Somewhat dry. Medium body with average carbonation. Another great beer from Alesmith. Thanks Peter.

7/23/10.  Big thanks to Tim for this puppy!  Big fresh fruity and citrus aroma with an almost sweettart lovliness.  The flavor is big sweet tropical fruits with a wonderful balanced bitterness.  This is stellar!

The absolute winner on our camping trip in mendocino. The hop levels and really nice citrus tones were really fantastic. The malt levels are nice and refreshing with no negative aftertaste. Really a great brew. Drank so nice and we wish we had more!

22oz. Bottle:  Sweet aroma of hops, crystal malt, light tropical fruit, slight pine, slight citrus, slight grapefruit, and a hint of orange.  Poured amber in color with a huge, foamy, creamy, dense, frothy, off-white head that diminished but lasted throughout.  Cloudy.  Sparkling.  Full of tiny, and a few small, particles throughout.  Flavor is light to medium sweet, and heavily bitter.  Tastes of hops, pine, resin, light tropical fruit, light grapefruit, crystal malt, slight grass, slight caramel, light wood, and a hint of vanilla.  Medium body.  Tingly, then dry texture.  Average to slightly lively carbonation.  Crystal malt, hops, resin, pine, light wood, slight tropical fruit, slight caramel, and slight grass finish is light to medium sweet and heavily bitter.  8.5%ABV is completely hidden throughout.

I like so totally rated this one like ten years ago, or something like that. Then these dudes, they went and split it into 2. Damn yall. So anyways... Bright orange, citrus, sweet. Quenching as hell, pine lashing, then a drop off. Ahhh. Its a holiday in my mouth.

Aroma:On first sniff, I get the delightful smell of sweet cotton candy! More subtle is some orange citrus smells.

Appearance:This beer has a pale golden color, with a nice thick head of white foam.

Taste:This beer is quite an eye opener at the first taste, because of the huge hoppy flavors. Once I can get past the pure bitterness, the grapefruit and pine flavor of the hops starts to come through. There is a fair amount of sweetness that tries to balance the hops, but falls short. The sheer amount of alcohol in this beer is more noticeable in the aftertaste than in the foretaste. Also on the aftertaste, once the bitterness recedes, the peach flavor lingers pleasantly.

Palate:The mouthfeel on this beer is kind of harsh, due to the huge amount of hops and alcohol.

Overall:I think I like this beer in small doses, as its so strong and hoppy, definitely a sipper.

UPDATED: JUL 18, 2012 650 ml bottle.  Pours a slightly hazy golden amber with a small white head that has decent retention and lacing.  The aroma is big grapefruit, light pine, light sugar cookie, and a bit of caramel .  The taste is sweet caramel, grapefruit, light pine, and a bit of sugar cookie.  The finish has a decent bitterness with some lingering pine.  Medium body.  Medium carbonation.  Quite good.  Not as good as the regular IPA, but still pretty tasty.

Pours a clear golden yellow colour with a frothy white head. Aroma of floral hops, citrus, pine, and malts. Has a flavour of bitter, tangy floral hops, pine, malts, and citrus. Dry finish, almost like a Chardonnay. Very palatable.

This is close to DIPA perfection, in my opinion.  It could use a touch more delicacy in the flavor, but the aroma is unique and memorable and thats worth a lot in this style.  The aroma is floral with some pine and peppery spice.  Its freshly hoppy, aggressive yet delicate.  The flavor is medium dry with lots of excellent bitterness.  Theres a strong bite in the finish and a fair bit of that peppery spice.  That spice reminds me of spicy greens, like pepper cress.  The body is nice and light with good carbonation.  The appearance is a medium gold liquid with a big and frothy white head.  This is an excellent beer, easy to like with a complex and full hop flavor.  Delicious.

very heady pour...had to let settle to finish.  pours a pale amber color with a hug, foamy white head...very lively.  outstanding retention and lacing.  aroma is very floral, light grass, citrus, and faint vanilla (might not have noticed if it werent for the commercial description but its there).  flavor is very hoppy with spice and grapefruit, lightly bready...hint of alcohol.  not overly complex but pretty tasty.  mouthfeel is resinous yet lively with a very long hoppy finish that sticks to your tongue.  outstanding beer.

Pours a foaming clear golden amber with a pillowy white head that wont go away, looks awesome even w the gigantic head... fresh pungent citrus hops, grapefruit is very dominant, some piney hops come through, not much malt character in the aroma... big body, warming, very citrusy, loads of flavor, not super clean though, lingering dryness, flavor doesnt match aroma as much as id like,

Bouteille de 22 oz, édition 2010, vieille de moins dun mois. Arômes intenses et complexes de houblon américain (pamplemousse, résine, pelures doranges). Robe dorée et légèrement trouble, belle mousse et effervescence assez active pour le style. Bien ronde et plutôt sucrée en bouche, la malt montre des belles notes de sucre dorge et de biscuits. Le houblon est très complexe et particulièrement porté sur les agrumes. Finale sucrée présentant une amertume fine et une touche dalcool. Très bon mais serait encore meilleur si moins sucré.

Pale golden pour lots of carbonation lots of off white head ... lots of thick lacing .... aroma of citrusy hops and sweet malts .... taste of citrusy hops and caramel malts with carbonation and a bitter hop punch that leads to a bitter spicy dry hop finish ...... after it settled for awhile it was much smoother and the citrus came out more along with some pine.... not bad alesmith can do better though

Cask at the Blind Tiger.  Pours a gently hazed yellow gold with a small creamy white head.  Wonderful pineapple and big tropical fruit.  A bit thin, though that could just be the cask.  A little caramel and vanilla, and a touch of alcohol.  Nice juicy hop flavors.  Long slow gentle grapefruit.

22 ounce bottle from the Davis Food Co-Op.  Aroma has a citrus melon-like hoppiness with a little pine character as well.  Has some sweet, candy sugared aromas present as well.  Lightly metallic.  Pours a golden body with a super large frothy whitish head that takes a while to dissipate.  Starts a bit sweet with some maltiness, before this becomes quite pine-like.  Has some toasted malts in the middle.  Has a fairly dry, grapefruity, hoppy finish with a noticeable ethanol presence.  This becomes rather harsh in the finish, and it is difficult to enjoy more than a few ounces.

Bottle...  Poured vibrant, golden, orange with a white head.  Aroma of alcohol, citrus, and hops.   Tasted of grapefruit, biscuits, sweet grains, lactose creaminess.  Finished a little hot with a hoppy flavor too.

Bottle. Clear golden with a creamy white head. The aroma is loads of peachy hops, caramel, pine, citrus and flowers. The flavour is piney, citrussy and floral with loads of caramel, some grape fruit and ends up with a warming alcohiolic feel among the piney citrussy hops. Lovely.

2010 Summer.  Amber colored brew with a big white head.  Mmmm, piney hoppy flavors are abundant in this holiday ale.  It has a big malt backbone that creates a wonderful balance.  Undercurrents of citrus with a slightly bitter finish.  To me this is a hopheads IPA, coming from epicenter of hoppy IPAs.  A tip of the hat to the San Diego (German for whales vagina) boys and Alesmith.

UPDATED: JUL 25, 2010 Bubbly head on a light orange body.  Excellent head retention and lacing.  Aroma is quite hoppy and a bit sweet.  Taste is good, though a bit more malt-forward than I would have liked.  It has a slightly sweet/syrupy quality, but not enough to kill it for me.  Definitely a well  done beer, but I actually prefer the standard AleSmith IPA to this.

UPDATED: JUN 9, 2012 Summer 2009

A: Pale amber body... hefty egg-shell white head. lasts for days. dense lacing left behind throughout

S: Blast of dense piney hops with some underlying grapefruit bitterness. light caramel malt.

T: Massive piney and grapefruit hop bitterness. fresh and profound. lively. nice malty, caramel base.

M: Smooth. Good carbonation levels. Refreshingly bitter.

O: A real treat. I look forward to both the summer and winter yulesmiths each year.

bomber from Lagunitasfan, shared with jsprime. pours deep orange with a tan head. big hoppy aroma with ample malt backing. big rich malty stucture supports the huge hops assult in the flavour. balanced but leaning towards hops for the most part. bigger malt structure then i was expecting but still enjoyable all around. great stuff.

Bottle courtesy of Secret Santa (DeadGirl).  Pours an orange color with a big fluffy head.  Good retention.  As soon as the bottle is cracked the hops invade the senses with notes of citrus, juicy grapefruit, and plenty of pine resin.  Light alcohol joins in shortly after.  The flavor follows for the most part; pine, orange peel, grapefruit, herbs, a little lemon, sharp long-lasting bitterness.  Theres also a healthy dose of sweet malt thats probably the right amount to balance while not being overdone.  Despite a little warming alcohol sting in the finish this is probably a thirst quenching of an IIPA as any out there.  Im not going to say this is the best Double IPA Ive had but it deserves to be in the conversation.  Thanks Amelia!!!

2010 release. 22 oz bottle. A hazy golden-orange beer with a huge beautiful head The aroma is very nice and hoppy with lots of citrus, orange, mango, grapefruit- basically tropical fruits and loads of em. The taste is very hoppy and is dominated  by tropical fruits and tastes like orange juice. This beer is very refreshing and goes down extremely easy and drinks like it has a low ABV. I really do like its citrusy tropical fruitiness and the head seems to leave a lasting layer of foam. This is a perfect summer release as it has some serious thirst quenching qualities.

Pours a cloudy orange with a large head. Tastes like something of a barley wine - packed with flavor, and hop forward, but theres far more malts in here than I thought there might be. Not exactly what I expected - I wanted more fresh, bitter hops. This is complex, and potent, but it doesnt live up to the hype.

22 0z bottle into a snifter.
Pours a lemon-orange with a huge pure white head. This head retention was as good as I have seen on an IPA and the lacing was extraordinary as well. Aroma is a wonderful nose of floral, pine, grapefruit, orange. The taste begins with some pineapple, grapefruit, peach and orange and some sweet malt (caramel/honey). This gives way to a little spice, some light bready notes and ends with a nice hop bite. Mouthfeel is creamy, medium with moderate carbonation. This beer has such a nice balance - nice edge/graininess and hops perfectly balanced with the sweetness of the malts both as you drink it and after. This is a great beer and one I will aggressively seek out again.

Enjoyed as part of a sampler at Stone World Bistro.  Aroma is of very spicy hops.  Appearance is of a standard IPA, more golden than amber.   Taste is of very pronounced spiced and citrus hops, smooth crisp finish.  This was extremely fantastic for its style, but I have had better IPAs before.
Big citrus hops aroma.  Delicious compounded hops taste.  Somewhat bitter, hard hitting malt/hops finish.  Quite the excellent IIPA.

UPDATED: AUG 27, 2016 bottle from Dorothy lane in Springboro.  Well balanced IPA, golden very slightly cloudy with a high level of carbonation, lots of yeast resudue at the bottom.  Modest head and a little lacing.  OK but not outstanding.
August 2016 alesmith has come to PA. Got a six pack at Wexford Pub at whole food.  Must be a lot fresher as it is great, full mouth, enough malts and juicy hops.  carbonation just right

UPDATED: AUG 1, 2010 New bottle, definitely this year, great extra from JonnyJ.

A-pours a transparent hazy bright gorange color with tons of a fulffy white head.

S-a good balance with stronger hop presence, the caramel malt sets the foundation, lots of spicy grassy hops, notes of citrus, touch of pine and some kind of medicinal phenol.

T-balanced malt presence, notes of caramel, tons of pine in the flavor, hoppy pine, light citrus notes, a good bit of spice with strong grassy herbal hop back.

M-syrupy and resignous, medium to full body, thick and chewy, good carbonation, almost a dry finish.

D-much better, solid imperial IPA, light balance with great hop flavors and a huge spicy profile which is quite intersting and nice.

******************

A-pours a clear golden orange color with particles floating around.  a tight creamy off white head with a thick lace left all over the glass.

S-the nose is huge and mostly a mix of pine, caramel, and burnt brown sugar.

T-the taste follows the nose, tons of brown sugar, slightly burnt, lots of caramel, and a touch of pine.  very faint bitterness and hint of booze in the back.

M-smooth, good carbonation on a medium body with a syrupy feel that coats the mouth.

D-imperial IPA?  huge malt base, more like a barleywine.  could this be last years???

SUMMER VERSION 22oz bomber sampled today.

Appearance: Honey orange colored and lighter around the edges. Nice 2-3 fingers of foam with lots of retention and lacing.

Smell: Lots of caramel malt sweetness, a boat load of hops, and a touch of alcohol.

Taste: exactly like the nose.

Mouthfeel: a touch syrupy and medium to medium full in body. The carbonation doesnt come through enough IMHO.

Drinkability: Good for the style but a touch too thick in body and under carbonated for me to keep kicking these back.

Not a bad brew at all but Im not a fan of so much caramel malt in my DIPAs. Its a fairly balanced DIPA for a West Coast offering.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 01-17-2009

Bottle. 

Golden orange with a white head lacing some lacings.

The smell is hoppy with a nice grapefruit/pine-needle character with hints of tobacco. Quite a lot of malts are shining through. 

The flavor is fairly sweet with a pleasant caramel malty backbone with notes of vanilla. Decent amount of aroma hops (pine-needles and grapefruit). Ends bitter with peppery and citric hops, and hints of warming alcohol. 

Medium to full body, easy on the palate and very easy to drink.

An enjoyable double IPA.

Bought 6 months ago at Papago, PhoenixIt pours a cloudy deep blond color, with generous, creamy head. Medium hop aroma, a bit puckery, delicate mix of citrus fruits. Good body, smooth mouthfeel; strong caramel and toffee flavor, with enough residual sweetness for my liking; the bitterness is strong, of good quality, without exceeding on the resiny or fruity side. Strong and long final, chewy too. Maybe not fresh, but very good.

This beer pours an amber color with a large head that has great retention and leaves nice lacing on the glass. The basis of the aroma is a caramel, but it is dominated by pine and citrus hops. The flavor is very smooth and well balanced. The caramel adds to the complexity and takes a bit of the bite from the hops. Very nice beer.

9-25-07

22oz bomber of Summer (07) Yulesmith.

1. Thanks for the recommendations-fellow BAs. The IPA recommendation column. This one has proven to be one of my favorite of the style so far.

2. Is this worth the hype??...yes it definitely is.

3. Well I was a bit scared to try this hop monster (since I was looking for the Xmas Yulesmith)

A-Body is a nice foggy rusty amber hue with plenty of cloudiness. Brew Pours with a big foamy 3 finger head that slowly fades to 1 finger and has perfect retention. Plenty of lacing is left behind in the glass (and the bottle). As I said with Alesmith IPA, I love the appearance of a good bottle fermented ale-and this is something you dont normally find with IPAs. Tiny bubbles constantly rise to the top (and Im drinking this from a standard pint glass not my tulip or chalice which is designed to enhance appearance.)

S- Big nose full of citrus hops-strong on grapefruit and refreshing-almost minty-pine hops. Subtly in the background is a nice caramel malt sweetness.

T- Big hop taste upfront. Refreshing piny hops make a big presence early in the taste with a background of citrus hop flavor and caramel malt. The finish is a big burst of piny and spicy hops with a subtlety of citrus hops and caramel malt rushing in to balance the flavor out. What lingers is low, but present, residual bitterness, lots of piny hop flavor, spicy hop flavor and a balance of sweet, bready malt.

P- Medium carbonation. Body is very oily, slightly yeasty, and smooth and creamy.

O- Bottle says 8.5% ABV yet it drinks like a session ale. There is not even a hint of alcohol warming at the end of the taste. This, indeed is one of my favorite DIPAs. I will make the trip out to OH just to buy more than one of these bottles next summer. I cant wait to try the winter version!

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 02-20-2008 20:20:08
Pours amber with a large off-white head. Aroma is malt, heavy hop, citrus, grapefuit and peach. Flavour has a nice malt base and heavy hop on top. The hop is citrus, peach and grapefruit. Nice beer.

Bottle. Pours a clear, light amber beer with a big offwhite head. The aroma is some sweetness and hops with citrus. The flavor follows the nose with some additional grapefruit. The palate is bitter. Overall a really good beer.

Poured courtesy of Paul (archimedes something on ratebeer). Poured a dark red/amber with a finger of head which stayed around for quite a bit. Taste has a very nice mixture of hops and sweet malts that balance each other out quite well. This is certainly one of the sweeter double ipas Ive had in a while. The hops are certainly on the citrusy side, but not overpowering. Alcohol is a bit noticeable on the aftetaste but not very noticeable. Very very nice double ipa.

Of all the beers Ive had, this is my favorite. I can acknowledge its not the very best Ive had (that honor goes to Westy 12), but its the one that I want to drink most often. I really couldnt ask for anything more in an IPA. A wildly refreshing drink, which makes me want to drink it with something really spicy. Taste is pretty much pine and floral, the way I like an IPA. Probably the distilled essence of a west coast American IPA. Dont miss out on this.
Light amber. Nice creamy head with long duration also in mouth.  Direct hoppy aroma.Bitter. Too bitter without big complexity. smoothy.
Bottle. Nice creamy head with good duration. Color is amber. Aroma and taste are rich hops and  flowers but also some caramel, grass and malt. Nice long bitter finish. Hides the alcohol well.

Bottle @ Odense Tasting, Feb 2010. Pours unclear golden with a small and thick white head and lacings. Nose is bready and sweet malty with some fruity hops beneath. Dry, fruity and hoppy flavor. Grapefruit and buiscuit. Smooth.... Very nice.

Pours a clear golden, white one finger head, from the 22oz. bottle into a tumbler: Aroma of sweet florals, pine, and sweet honeydew. Tastes of light hops, balanced malts, and very light citrus. Crisp mouthfeel. I know this is more of a generic rating, especially for my pretty low rating compared to the average, but its just not all coming together for me. Drinkability: sweet and light. Pairing: burger. Rebuy: yes- I need to rerate. #297 on 25022010, DG.

Amber unfiltered with lumps. Nice head, retention many bubble sizes.

Hoppy aroma.fresh. complex.

Bitter. Simple.

Medium body, mouthwatering due to bitterness.

Not all I had hoped. Too bitter without complexity. Nice head, not nice lumps.


Purchased in ølbutikken.

Bomber via trade with phaleslu, thanks Peter! Pours hazy peachy, pale copper with a chunky 2-3 finger off white yellowish head that has great retention and leaves nice sheets of lacing. Aroma is caramel, pink grapefruit flesh, orange blossom, light biscuit, a pleasant touch of pine, a sweet grainy note and a nice hint of melon on the tail end. Nice, there is a mellow, sweet smelling almost nutty note that I cant pin down too. Flavor is caramel, husky grain, sweet orange, toasted white bread, a very appealing pine note, fruity floral hops, and again a sweet nutty note that I cant quite describe, almost like a sweet almond, but not quite. Finishes with dark caramel, sweet orange, pink grapefruit, a touch of young pine needles and a nice grassiness.  Palate is medium bodied, and moderately carbonated with a creamy entry and off dry, though still slightly creamy finish. A really nice IIPA I think it has probably lost some of its original pep (being something like 8 months old), but retains a nice, hoppy character. I really have to try to get my mitts on this when its fresh.

Hazy orange colour with a dense white head that leaves some amazing lazing on the snifter. Aroma is very balanced of fruity and very light caramelly malt, fruity and piney, slightly perfumey hops with prominent grapefruit notes. Flavour delivers what the aroma promises plus a big dose of sweet fruity malts and a more than expected bitter and dry finish. Very balanced, clean and drinkable (like a 6-7ABV IPA.) Mouthfeel is lively with quite harsh carbonation, keeps things drinkable though, dangerously so. Another winner from Alesmith  which would probably have blowed my mind if I tried a truly fresh bottle..

A: Hazy pale gold/yellow color with one finger of fluffy white head.

S: Citrus hops (mostly grapefruit and some lemon) and pineapple. A fruity sweetness.

T: Grapefruit twang, pineapple, a nice bitterness but it certainly doesnt stick around long.

M: Nice medium body, slick mouthfeel.

D: Great fruit character, which I wasnt expecting. A most tasty beverage.

Bottle. Pours a slightly hazy pale golden color with a long lasting white head. Fruity fresh hoppy grapefruit and pine needles aroma. Fruity malty hoppy bitter grapefruit flavor. Has a long hoppy bitter grapefruit finish with a long and very bitter aftertaste.

Bottle thanks to DuffManSW.  Clear gold in color with a huge, meringue like white head that really hangs around for a while.  The aroma is lush with evergreen and bright zesty citrus notes.  The malt lends a subtly sweet toffee and biscuit layer to the aroma.  Evergreen and juniper flavors jump out at first and quickly blend in with lots of fresh grapefruit and orange notes.  Toasty and sweet caramel malt flavor rounds it out with some lingering honey and bitterness on the finish.  The body is creamy with a medium viscosity and soft but plentiful carbonation.

22 oz. bottle from Jungle Jims.  Pours a clear gold color with an inch-thick eggshell white head that laces the glass.  It gets cloudier as it goes down, with a lot of visible yeast sediment at the bottom.  Aroma of orange citrus, hops, caramel malts, vanilla, floral notes, and pine.  The flavor doesnt quite live up to that, but still has nice notes of orange and grapefruit citrus, caramel malts, floral hops, honey, pineapple, and pine.  Some warming alcohol.  Light-medium bodied, with a good bite from the carbonation, very crisp.  Bitter and sweet all the way through, even in the aftertaste, which has hops and honey.  Nice DIPA, though I would like to re-rate when fresher.
From bomber.  Pours deep amber with a thick head   Nose is full of pine and citrus.  The citrusy hops come through strong. Somewhat thin, carbonated but well balanced.  Alcohol is well hidden.

Bottle.  Silly me, I thought this was a Christmas Holiday ale.  Oh well -- Im a couple months late for this summer beer.  Nice pour of golden amber with a standing foam lid.  The aroma is quite woodsy -- like dry pine needles ready to be ignited.  This drinks with a wicked undertow of an alcoholic kick, but on the surface is a pleasantly hoppy little beer.  The final flourish is almost furniture polish ... but that sounds negative when it isnt.  Nice.  (#3783, 1/2/2010)

Flaske: Orange gul øl med en del kæmpe protein klumper i der ødelagde den sidste del af øllen, derfor et fradrag i udseende. Duften er helt fantastisk. Humle, tropisk frugt med en let citrus gør den umiskendelig vestkyst på den rigtig gode måde. Smagen er også lige i skabet, men knap så fantastisk. Mundfylden er blid og blød. Ville elske at prøve denne øl frisk.

Thanks to rasmus B for picking this one up for me.
pours a clear orange with a smooth lacing thick offwhite head. looks very good.
aroma can be sensed 30cms awaay from the glass i just poured. strong flowery hoppy aroma, delicate, getting your attention. getting closer to the glass i get a near perfect strong pine and flowery hops combination with some malty sweetness thrown in. it could be a little stronger but what we have is hard to improve on.
